data.title: How Beyonc√© turned herself into a pop god
data.meta_description: From surprise albums to Beychella to ‚ÄúBreak My Soul‚Äù: Behind the singer‚Äôs 10-year journey to cultural dominance.
data.text:
Beyonc√©‚Äôs latest solo album, Renaissance, released at the end of July, was greeted with the kind of critical rapture that is now the standard for her work.

The new album ‚Äúsucceeds exquisitely,‚Äù said Vulture. Beyonc√©‚Äôs singing, wrote Wesley Morris in the New York Times, comes ‚Äúin waves of rhapsodically long, Olympic-level emissions‚Äù and ‚Äúseems to emanate from somewhere way beyond a human throat: The ocean?‚Äù Renaissance, Rolling Stone argued, proved Beyonc√© to be ‚Äúthe only sovereign of pop to have truly evolved artistically while also expanding an enormous commercial empire.‚Äù

Beyonc√©‚Äôs artistic, commercial, and cultural evolution is one of the most important pop culture stories of the past decade. It made Beyonc√© one of the most important cultural figures of this decade, catapulting her to rarified air in 10 carefully calculated years.

When Beyonc√© dropped her first solo album, Dangerously in Love, in 2003, she did not get the sort of plaudits she receives today. While Rolling Stone allowed that she ‚Äúoozes charisma and has a fine voice,‚Äù it felt that she ‚Äúisn‚Äôt in a class with the likes of Whitney Houston or Mariah Carey as a singer.‚Äù Slant Magazine, in a largely positive review, described her as a cross between J. Lo and Mariah Carey, pop progeny with Lopez‚Äôs attitude and Carey‚Äôs pipes. The New York Times offered up a headline that would, nearly two decades later, be endlessly memed: ‚ÄúThe Solo Beyonc√©: She‚Äôs No Ashanti.‚Äù

At the beginning of her solo career, Beyonc√© was one among any number of pop stars, famous and admired the same way a lot of musicians are: her music beloved by some and uncontroversially ignored or disliked by others. A star, certainly, but a star with peers.

But over the past decade, Beyonc√© pulled herself out of that group. She became a critical consensus pick for one of the greatest artists of her generation. She redefined the textbook strategy for an album release. She turned her headliner Coachella gig into a legend of a night, and then a Netflix special. It became slightly controversial to say that her music wasn‚Äôt to your taste. It would be like not liking the Beatles.

How did she do it? How did Beyonc√© go from ‚Äúno Ashanti‚Äù in 2003 to being declared by Rolling Stone ‚Äúthe world‚Äôs greatest living entertainer‚Äù in 2022? How did her greatness become an apparent fact of the universe, to the point that the Grammys‚Äô refusal to give her an Album of the Year award after nominating her three times is widely discussed as proof of something terribly wrong inside the Grammys?

It happened, as everything else in Beyonc√©‚Äôs life seems to have happened, as the result of incredibly hard work and a highly controlled plan from the woman herself. The transformation of Beyonc√© from well-liked pop star to cultural icon came in three phases, punctuated by the self-titled Beyonc√© album of 2013, 2016‚Äôs Lemonade, and 2018‚Äôs Homecoming concert at Coachella.

Here‚Äôs how Beyonc√© turned herself into Beyonc√©.

Phase 1: Change the game

To be clear: Beyonc√© was already extremely famous before Beyonc√©.

By the time Beyonc√© dropped her self-titled album in 2013, she had already released four solo albums. All received moderate critical acclaim, with some caveats.

After Dangerously In Love (‚ÄúNo Ashanti‚Äù) in 2003 came 2006‚Äôs B‚ÄôDay (‚ÄúBy resolving the criticisms of her earlier work ... Beyonc√© has weakened her perfect pop technique‚Äù). B‚ÄôDay was followed by 2008‚Äôs I Am ... Sasha Fierce, by which time the Guardian was acknowledging Beyonc√© as ‚Äúthe queen of R&B,‚Äù but also coming after her, arguing that ‚ÄúHalo‚Äù sounded too much like Rihanna‚Äôs ‚ÄúUmbrella.‚Äù 2011‚Äôs 4 came with an acknowledgment from Rolling Stone that Beyonc√© was ‚Äúthe diva of divas,‚Äù as well as a warning from the Washington Post that she might have already hit her peak: The album, the critic wrote, smacked ‚Äúof a once-great blockbuster movie franchise sadly spinning its wheels.‚Äù

Beyonc√©, meanwhile, was constantly working. She had two major movie roles: a supporting part in 2006‚Äôs Dreamgirls, with mixed reviews (New York magazine brutally dismissed her as ‚Äúnot an actress‚Äù), and another in 2008‚Äôs Cadillac Records, this time to raves. (‚ÄúAs for Beyonc√©‚Äîoh my goodness,‚Äù said Slate.) She went on multiple world tours, on which the reviews were never mixed but still managed to be a little condescending (‚ÄúA revue spectacular enough in its colossal divadom to put off proclamations of ‚Äî it‚Äôs all right, we‚Äôve all felt it ‚Äî Beyonc√© fatigue.‚Äù) She sang as the Obamas danced their first dance as president and first lady in 2009 (‚ÄúBeyonc√© is fast becoming a saint‚Äù). With 2008‚Äôs ‚ÄúSingle Ladies,‚Äù she delivered what Kanye West would memorably declare ‚Äúone of the best videos of all time! One of the best videos of all time!‚Äù

By 2013, Beyonc√© had cemented herself as a major solo star. But she was not yet the kind of artist to whom critics offer unmitigated praise. She was not the queen of pop culture, but the queen of R&B. She was ‚Äúthe diva of divas,‚Äù but maybe on a downward slope. People could conceive of the possibility of ‚ÄúBeyonc√© fatigue.‚Äù

Looking at 2013 in retrospect, you can see Beyonc√© try out one strategy after another to change all that, to begin her ascent from queen of a genre to queen of us all.

That year was Beyonc√©‚Äôs post-pregnancy comeback year. Having given birth to her first child, Blue Ivy, in 2012, she marked her return to the public stage with a buzzy GQ profile in January 2013. ‚ÄúMiss Millennium,‚Äù read the headline.

As January went on, Beyonc√©‚Äôs pop culture offensive continued. She sang the national anthem at Obama‚Äôs second inauguration. She headlined the Super Bowl halftime show. She financed, directed, produced, narrated, and starred in Life Is But a Dream, an HBO documentary. She also launched a campaign as the face of Pepsi.

Not all of those moves were unalloyed successes. Beyonc√© faced a backlash when it came out that she was lip-syncing ‚ÄúThe Star Spangled Banner‚Äù at the inauguration. While her Super Bowl performance was a hit, Life Is But a Dream was an outright flop. The New York Times called it an ‚Äúinfomercial.‚Äù Variety dismissed it as a ‚Äúwearisome ‚Ä¶ vanity project.‚Äù Most damningly, the Guardian scoffed at the film‚Äôs framing of Beyonc√© as a feminist, a facet of her star image that was just beginning to come into particular focus. ‚ÄúDelusional,‚Äù guffawed the review. The only part of the movie that came off well was the footage of Beyonc√© putting together a performance of ‚ÄúWho Run the World‚Äù at the Billboard Music Awards, complete with graphic video projections. ‚ÄúCrisp, sparkling and vibrant,‚Äù the A.V. Club opined of that section. ‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt have minded more behind the scenes stuff.‚Äù

By that point, however, Beyonc√© had begun to hit cultural saturation. She was everywhere ‚Äî ‚Äúon Pepsi cans, L‚ÄôOreal billboards and the covers of GQ, Vogue and Forbes,‚Äù wrote the New York Times. ‚ÄúIn terms of exposure, the star‚Äôs flame has probably never burned brighter,‚Äù admitted Variety.

In the A.V. Club, Claire Zulkey described watching the Super Bowl with two 65-year-old men who found themselves flummoxed by the star: ‚ÄúThey do not get,‚Äù Zulkey wrote, ‚Äúwhat the big deal is with Beyonc√©.‚Äù

Beyonc√© was everywhere, unavoidable and inescapable. But had she justified her omnipresence? What would it take to get two 65-year-old white men to comprehend the fact of her?

In April, she launched her Mrs. Carter Show world tour. Like all Beyonc√© live performances, this one pulled rave reviews. But critics were still treating her as one pop star among many.

‚ÄúBeside her arena pop rivals, she was not as cool and dirty as Rihanna, not as physical and funny as Pink, and not as weird as Lady Gaga,‚Äù wrote the UK‚Äôs Standard. ‚ÄúBut she had a star wattage that was blinding, an ability to sing and dance and be mesmerising without the light beams and glitter cannons.‚Äù

There‚Äôs an exact moment at which that line of criticism came to an end and reviews began to acknowledge that Beyonc√© had transcended her peers. That‚Äôs when she surprise-dropped her fifth album, Beyonc√©, at the end of 2013.

Beyonc√© appeared quietly on iTunes that December, with no CDs available in record stores. The only announcement its star made was a post to her Instagram. The single, ‚ÄúXO,‚Äù would be announced days after the album itself dropped. On release day, every song came with its own video.

Otherwise, there was not a word of pre-promotion, publicity, or advertising for Beyonc√© ‚Äî except in the sense that the entire year had been one long advertisement for Beyonc√© herself.

The album was an immediate hit, commercially and critically. From a business angle, the surprise drop was a masterstroke. At the time, leaks of heavily anticipated albums were common, and music sales were on a downswing. With one move, Beyonc√© solved both problems ‚Äî eliminating leaks and drumming up buzz ‚Äî so effectively that other stars would continue emulating her strategy for the next nine years.

The release strategy wouldn‚Äôt have mattered, though, if the album weren‚Äôt great. Beyonc√© garnered some of the most glowing criticism Beyonc√© had received in her career. The same narrative appeared in every single review: Beyonc√© had just lapped her competition.

‚ÄúYou get the sense that Lady Gaga or Ciara could no sooner pull off the scale or quality of Beyonc√© than you or I could pull off a suitable rendition of any of its songs in a karaoke bar,‚Äù marveled Pitchfork.

‚ÄúOnly massive hubris could have made a feat like this album possible,‚Äù decreed Rolling Stone. ‚ÄúAnd Beyonc√©‚Äôs hubris makes the world a better, more Beyonc√©-like place.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot only does ‚ÄòBeyonc√©‚Äô rank as the year‚Äôs most accomplished and engaging mainstream pop album by a rather laughable margin,‚Äù said Variety, ‚Äúbut its calculatedly shrugged-off release strategy can‚Äôt help but read as an imperious kiss-off toward the singer‚Äôs competitors for the 2013 crown ‚Äî Lady Gaga, Justin Timberlake, Miley Cyrus, Katy Perry, and even her husband Jay Z ‚Äî all of whom worked up gallons of sweat and employed every eyeball-grabbing trick in the book to move their product, only to be upstaged by Beyonce‚Äôs abrupt digital data-dump.‚Äù

Within six months, the New York Times magazine had made the shift explicit. ‚ÄúA few years ago, Beyonc√© Knowles was like any other record-breaking pop star in an already crowded field,‚Äù wrote Jody Rosen. ‚ÄúThen something changed.‚Äù Beyonc√© arrived.

‚ÄúWe can only imagine the feelings of Beyonc√©‚Äôs pop diva competitors, whose carefully plotted monthslong album rollouts were instantly rendered quaint, and moot,‚Äù the Times went on. ‚ÄúThat whining, whirring sound you heard on Dec. 13, mingling with the strains of ‚ÄòDrunk in Love‚Äô ‚Äî that was Lady Gaga, in her gloomy castle keep, chainsawing a meat dress into sackcloth.‚Äù

If 2013 was a series of test runs for Beyonc√©, it provided her with some very clear data. Judging from the reception of Life Is But a Dream, while talking in public did nothing to serve her mystique, people did seem to respond well to her visual imagination. Critics loved getting an inside look at how she created her VMA video projections in Life Is But a Dream, and parsing the significance of images in her new visual album became a beloved fan hobby. The reception of Beyonc√© showed that the element of surprise could offer a substantial advantage. But nothing else mattered unless the work was great ‚Äî so Beyonc√©, it became clear, would always be great.

Phase 2: Up the game

In the wake of Beyonc√©, Queen Bey‚Äôs profile had changed for good. She had always had fans, but now the Beyhive was bigger and more vocal than ever.

In May 2014, SNL lampooned the now-widespread Beyonc√© worship with a sketch titled The Beygency. When one man dares to say that he‚Äôs ‚Äúnot a huge fan‚Äù of ‚ÄúDrunk in Love,‚Äù he‚Äôs forced on the run from Beyonc√©‚Äôs ferocious fans. ‚ÄúHe turned against his country,‚Äù intones the narrator, ‚Äúand its queen.‚Äù

Meanwhile, Beyonc√© herself ‚Äî perhaps taking a lesson from the critical response to Life Is But a Dream ‚Äî had stopped talking in public. She landed the prestigious September 2015 cover of Vogue without granting the magazine an interview. In May 2015, the New York Times learned that she hadn‚Äôt answered a direct question in over a year. What‚Äôs more, she didn‚Äôt have to. She was still on the covers of magazines across newsstands, and her music was still selling.

‚ÄúIf she is avoiding the news media, it is not avoiding her,‚Äù the Times concluded. She was still ‚Äúarguably the biggest star of the moment.‚Äù

Then, in 2016, came Lemonade. Like Beyonc√©, Lemonade had an unconventional and visuals-heavy album rollout. It first appeared on HBO as a quasi-pop art film, each song rolling into the next over enigmatic and evocative imagery, interspersed with excerpts from poetry by Warsan Shire. The music premiered exclusively on Tidal, the streaming platform partially owned by Beyonc√©‚Äôs husband, rapper Jay-Z.

And Lemonade, critics agreed, was at another artistic level entirely. Unique among Beyonc√© albums, it has a clear narrative throughline. It‚Äôs the tale of how Beyonc√© survived Jay-Z‚Äôs infidelity, of how she pushed through and rebuilt her marriage after his betrayal. It was also the first explicitly political Beyonc√© album. Jay-Z‚Äôs personal betrayal of Beyonc√© became a metaphor for America‚Äôs betrayal of Black women, and the album as a whole became a celebration of the solidarity and sisterhood of Black womanhood. The result was deeply personal, with a ferocious political bite, and it emerged just as Donald Trump‚Äôs racist presidential campaign was roiling American politics.

Critics had already begun to agree that Beyonc√© was peerless. Now, she was more even than that.

‚ÄúBeyonc√© is less pop star or musician or even icon, at this point, than she is a belief system,‚Äù said Vanity Fair.

‚ÄúAwe has always seemed like the only appropriate response to Beyonc√©, a star who makes even the best of the rest look a bit amateur,‚Äù said the Guardian. Not only was Beyonc√© awe-inspiring, the review went on, she was now, in new and exciting ways, politically relevant. ‚ÄúBeyonc√©‚Äôs subject emerges as nothing less than the black female body, the police state and black lives past and present. The lemonade that she‚Äôs making in her 34th year isn‚Äôt just from the bitter juice of her famous husband‚Äôs infidelities, it‚Äôs the pain of black mothers and grandmothers and their mothers. Suddenly, she is doing something so much bigger than telling us she‚Äôs the flyest.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs nothing else like‚Äù the way Beyonc√© commands our attention, concluded Jenna Wortham in the New York Times, ‚Äúperiod.‚Äù

At the 2017 Grammys, when Lemonade lost Album of the Year to Adele‚Äôs 25, Kanye West didn‚Äôt have to rush the stage to proclaim the loss an outrage. Adele did it for him.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt possibly accept this award,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm very humbled and very grateful and gracious, but my artist of my life is Beyonc√©. The Lemonade album was so monumental.‚Äù

Phase 3: Don‚Äôt ever come back down to earth

Six years passed between Lemonade and Renaissance without a new solo album from Beyonc√©, but she stayed in the public eye. And in that time, she kept pushing the public to watch her not just as a star, but as an artist. Every move she made was rich with layers of meaning.

In 2017, she announced first her pregnancy and then the birth of her twins with lavish photo shoots laced with divine goddess imagery. In photographs, she was variously the Virgin Mary, Venus, and the Yoruba Oshun. During her 2017 Grammys performance, she briefly became both Kali and Christ. ‚ÄúI am Osun,‚Äù she announced on Black Is King, the visual album she curated in 2020, referring again to the Yoruba goddess of love, sensuality, and femininity.

In 2018, Beyonc√© became the first Black woman to headline Coachella. The concert she delivered, later immortalized as a live album and a concert film, was titled Homecoming. Spanning her whole career, from the Destiny‚Äôs Child days to the present, it was built as a celebration of the homecoming traditions of historically Black colleges and universities, complete with a marching band and fraternity rushes. It was hailed by critics uniformly as an inarguable masterpiece.

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs just cut to the chase: There‚Äôs not likely to be a more meaningful, absorbing, forceful and radical performance by an American musician this year, or any year soon, than Beyonc√©‚Äôs headlining set at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival on Saturday night,‚Äù ran the New York Times review from Jon Caramanica.

For Caramanica, Homecoming was further proof that Beyonc√© had become essentially peerless. ‚ÄúShe is one of the only working pop stars,‚Äù Caramanica wrote, ‚Äúwho need not preoccupy herself with prevailing trends, or the work of her peers. She is an institution now, and that has allowed her freedom.‚Äù

Moreover, the night was proof that her Grammys loss was a glitch at best. ‚ÄúThat space on the mantel will be filled by a National Medal of the Arts, or a Presidential Medal of Freedom,‚Äù Caramanica concluded. ‚ÄúLike no other musician of her generation apart from Kanye West, Beyonc√© is performing musicology in real time. It is bigger than any tribute she might receive. History is her stage.‚Äù

Beychella, as it came to be called, was a coronation, an ascension, an apotheosis. It was Beyonc√© informing the world once again that she was a goddess, and the world at last uniting at her feet in agreement.

The shift was complete. Beyonc√© was no longer ‚Äúno Ashanti,‚Äù no longer someone to be compared to Lady Gaga or Rihanna, no longer someone even to be compared to Michael Jackson or the Beatles. She was playing on a different level.

So by the time Renaissance premiered in July 2022, Beyonc√© no longer had anything to prove.

Renaissance doesn‚Äôt come with the overt political agenda of Lemonade or Homecoming. Its songs are mostly about how dancing and sex are fun things that Beyonc√© enjoys doing. In contrast to Beyonc√©, Renaissance‚Äôs album rollout was, if anything, notable for its conventionality. It was announced six weeks ahead of its release, with an interview in Vogue UK. It came without any of Beyonc√©‚Äôs now trademark lavish visuals. The album was even leaked the day before its release.

But by now, Beyonc√© has earned enough credit that no one is sneering at her for making an album that‚Äôs mostly about pleasure, released in a conventional way. We can take for granted that all these things are worthwhile because why else would Beyonc√© be singing about it?

That status, as Beyonc√© has been hinting for the past few years in the occasional highly controlled interviews she‚Äôs begun to allow again, is where she‚Äôs been aiming for a good long while now.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve spent so many years trying to better myself and improve whatever I‚Äôve done that I‚Äôm at a point where I no longer need to compete with myself,‚Äù she said to Harper‚Äôs Bazaar in 2020.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve spent a lot of time focusing on building my legacy and representing my culture the best way I know how,‚Äù she told Vogue UK in 2020. ‚ÄúNow, I‚Äôve decided to give myself permission to focus on my joy.‚Äù

Joy as in: dance music. Riding a horse in the nightclub. Releasing the wiggle.

‚ÄúCan Beyonc√© Go Back to Just Being a Pop Star?‚Äù Slate asked when Renaissance dropped. No, of course she can‚Äôt.

But in the rarified pop universe where she reigns, Beyonc√© has also built herself a celestial place to play.

Correction, August 16, 2:50 pm: An earlier version of this article misidentified the platform Beyonc√©‚Äôs Homecoming concert film appeared on. It was Netflix. The article also misstated which performance of ‚ÄúWho Run the World‚Äù Beyonce prepared for in the documentary Life Is But a Dream. It was for the Billboard Music Awards.
